item.title: Optimizing R Shiny Docker Builds: Warm vs Cold Build Strategy
item.author: noreply@sumedhsankhe.github.io (Sumedh R. Sankhe)
item.description:
How we optimized Docker builds for a customer-facing R Shiny SaaS application by separating code changes (8-15 min) from dependency changes (40 min) and reduced image sizes by 42%. Learn the practical techniques that transformed our CI/CD pipeline at Alamar Biosciences.

This is my first time writing up a technical blog post, so bear with me. I'm going to share what we learned optimizing Docker builds for R Shiny apps, including the things that broke along the way.

At Alamar Biosciences, I work on the NULISA Analysis Software (NAS) - a large-scale, customer-facing SaaS application for analyzing proteomics data, built with R Shiny and running on Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).

Key Results:

  • Image sizes reduced by 42% (1.5GB → 870MB compressed in ACR)
  • Warm builds (code changes): 60-68% faster (20-25 mins → 8-15 mins)
  • Cold builds (dependency changes): 40 mins (longer but comprehensive and cached)
